Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Several of them said they were confused by the arrests because they had been allowed to register to vote.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Several of them said they were confused by the arrests because they had been allowed to register to vote.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Three of the witnesses with criminal records who spoke in favor of the legislation said in later interviews the waiting period is not a deterrent to future crime, but rather a barrier for those who have served their sentences.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: three of the witnesses with criminal records
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Three of the witnesses with criminal records who spoke in favor of the legislation said in later interviews the waiting period is not a deterrent to future crime, but rather a barrier for those who have served their sentences.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: At least 14 states have introduced proposals this year focused on restoration of voting rights, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.
Document Sources.Source Justification: according to the Brennan Center for Justice

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: More than 4.6 million people are disenfranchised in the United States because of felony convictions, according to the Sentencing Project, which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons.
Document Sources.Source Justification: according to the Sentencing Project, which studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Voting, King said in an interview, gives “a little bit of your strength back and a little bit of your voice back. Being able to vote, being able to have a say in what happens in your society, in your state, is extremely important.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: An outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project, King came off probation in August after serving time for drug and theft convictions.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Restoring voting rights really is an issue where we’ve seen bipartisan momentum,” said Patrick Berry, counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Patrick Berry, counsel for the Democracy program at the Brennan Center

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In Nebraska, nearly 18,000 people are unable to vote because of felony convictions, said the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy, Nicole Porter.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: director of advocacy at the Sentencing Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Nicole Porter, the Sentencing Project’s director of advocacy

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “You’re civically dead and you can’t vote for the people who are levying those taxes,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Steve Smith of Civic Nebraska, part of a large coalition of groups supporting the measure

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The bill’s author, Democratic state Sen. Justin Wayne, said he was going door to door in his first election in 2016 and was told by would-be constituents that they could not vote.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: The bill’s author, Democratic state Sen. Justin Wayne

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I do think that hopefully the waiting period reinforces the fact that voting is something very special, and hopefully that will be part of the things that an individual would consider if they’re tempted to break the law again,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kathy Wilcot, a member of the University of Nebraska Board of Regents, was the lone dissenter from among the nearly 20 witnesses who spoke on Wayne’s bill.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I felt so hopeless and helpless not being able to have my voice heard in this last election,” King said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: King works in the HIV/AIDS field and volunteers at various organizations, but said voting is still the most direct way to be involved and became tearful when talking about being unable to vote.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I don’t have a say in anything that goes on in my country because I’m a felon.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Demetrius Gatson is among the more than 10,000 people in Nebraska who has no right to vote because they haven’t completed their sentences.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “You can’t harm society by voting,” he said. “You can only help it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: owner of a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Steven Scott, 33, was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges.
